text.sentence: Consumer | U.S. Cosmetics; Household and Personal Care three November two thousand fifteen Stock Rating
Both threeQ results and management's full year outlook validated the factors we focused on in our analysis of CHD's top line potential last week.

With toughening comparisons and a slow recovery in the Vitamins business being well understood constraints on growth heading into twoH, it came as no surprise to us that management chose to keep its top line outlook for the full year intact even with stronger than expected performance this quarter.
We found commentary on Laundry and Vitamins to be analogous to our impressions of changing dynamics in the two categories discussed last week.
Looking at Laundry, with a second consecutive quarter of growth under its belt following three years of declines, the category does appear to be stabilizing.

However, while CEO Jim Craigie's update on the state of the consumer was probably the most positive we have heard in some time, management was quick to point out that while a rising tide lifts all boats, it doesn't do so equally and that the path forward for the value end of the Laundry category isn't without challenges.

Turning to Vitamins, while we'd suggested that softer trends were here to stay, what struck us as interesting was that unlike in quarters past, management also appeared more conservative around top line trends.
Even in the absence of acquisitions, the company is proactively seeking out new avenues of growth via its power brand strategy.
While the desire for material and accretive M and A has been unrequited of late, the company appears to be tapping into its past deal well to accelerate growth.
Specifically, we were surprised to hear so much attention paid to Batiste, a dry shampoo brand acquired in two thousand eleven.
By our math, the business has grown at a ~thirty percent CAGR to date, with sales expected to reach ~ dollar one hundredmm next year and achieve power brand status.
Church has crafted plans for a more aggressive expansion in the US .
While plenty of mainstream beauty brands have already launched dry shampoos, we'd actually think the more niche positioning of Batiste could work to drive category sales growth .

While we commend CHD for its ability to consistently deliver strong EPS growth, we find its premium valuation in light of slower organic sales growth more grounded in potential for M and A. With recent deals within Staples showing buyer multiples contracting, we believe current valuation will prove stretched even should an attractive deal be announced.
Church and Dwight gets better than expected gross margin expansion, consumers continue to trade down and commodity inflation dissipates.
Based on +fifteen percent premium multiple to Large Cap with +ten percent EPS growth in Csixteen.
Innovation across portfolio has less of an impact than initially expected.
Based on a ~nineteenx multiple on our base case Csixteen EPS estimate of dollar three.forty

Yesterday, Church and Dwight reported threeQfifteen Core EPS of dollar .ninety, which compares to Barclays dollar .eighty
In truth, CHD valuation has always been a challenge for us as it has habitually been one of the more richly valued names in our sector.

At times, this valuation premium has reflected fundamentals that were far better than peers and it has habitually been tied to hopes for accretive and growth enhancing M and A. Today, while M and A hopes are unrequited and growth has become a bit tougher, the stock has retained its premium given its US centric and oil exposed business mix.
As such, we'd expect the stock to be weak once this defensive trade unwinds, particularly as the company's own long term growth expectations are now lower than they were just a few years ago.
Our dollar eighty one price target reflects a more muted ~five percent premium multiple to Large Cap Staples peers on our revised Csixteen EPS estimate of dollar three.forty
Both threeQ results and management's full year outlook validated the factors we focused on in our analysis of CHD's top line potential last week.

With toughening comparisons and a slow recovery in the Vitamins business being well understood constraints on growth heading into twoH, it came as no surprise to us that management chose to keep its top line outlook for the full year intact even with stronger than expected performance this quarter.
We found commentary on Laundry and Vitamins to be analogous to our impressions of changing dynamics in the two categories discussed last week .
Looking at Laundry, with a second consecutive quarter of growth under its belt following three years of declines, the category does appear to be stabilizing.

However, while CEO Jim Craigie's update on the state of the consumer was probably the most positive we have heard in some time, management was quick to point out that while a rising tide lifts all boats, it doesn't do so equally and that the path forward for the value end of the Laundry category isn't without challenges.

In this vein, we give the company credit for thinking ahead to a time when growth would be more skewed toward the higher end of the pricing spectrum and developing an OxiClean liquid laundry detergent, launched in oneQfourteen.

Still, we think the path to establishing the brand in the laundry category has been tougher than anticipated and the step up in trade support was perhaps a decision made intra quarter as the company got a sense for how retailers were looking to reorient store shelves early next year.
Our understanding is that it isn't straightforward to keep shelf space for a product that has less than a two percent market share nearly two years after its initial launch.

While we did learn on the call that OxiClean will be gaining distribution at two new retailers in fourQ, we would think shelf space could come at the expense of Arm and Hammer facings on some of its ancillary, low turn line extensions, so a good trade assuming Oxi picks up steam.

Turning to Vitamins, while we'd suggested that softer trends were here to stay, what struck us as interesting was that unlike in quarters past, management also appeared more conservative around top line trends.

Specifically, while supply chain issues appear to have been resolved and distribution, is back at levels seen prior to the twoQ setback, growth numbers thrown out during the Q and A suggested Avid trending more in the mid single digit range going forward vs. the double digit pace we have heard management echo since the business was acquired in two thousand twelve.
Even in the absence of acquisitions, the company is proactively seeking out new avenues of growth via its power brand strategy.

Church and Dwight's growth strategy has long been to enhance its revenue growth and margin profile with M and A, with power brands like Oxi Clean and Vitafusion having been added to the portfolio over the past decade.
In reality, as successful as Oxi has been, there have been misses on this front too, namely the Orajel and Unilever oral care acquisitions being front of mind.
Notably, we think Street perception is that the company has been far more acquisitive than is factually the case as its largest
Barclays | Church and Dwight Co., Inc. brands outside of Arm and Hammer generally came to the company through the two thousand one CarterWallace deal.
While the desire for material and accretive M and A has been unrequited of late, the company is tapping into its past deal well to accelerate growth.
Specifically, we were surprised to hear so much attention paid to Batiste, a dry shampoo brand acquired in two thousand eleven.
By our math, the business has grown at a ~thirty percent CAGR to date, with sales expected to reach ~ dollar one hundredmm next year and achieve power brand status.
Church has crafted plans for a more aggressive expansion in the US .
While plenty of mainstream beauty brands have already launched dry shampoos, we'd actually think the more niche positioning of Batiste could work to drive category sales growth .

We are lowering our outlook for fourQ organic sales growth to +.five percent as we expect stronger International sales to be offset by weaker momentum domestically, bringing our full year estimate for organic sales growth to +three.one
We expect gross margins to expand +forty bps to forty four.five
percent driven by normalized pricing trends in Laundry as well as easing commodities, offset slightly by currency headwinds and increased couponing behind OxiClean.
percent and SG and A and R and D flat YoY, we're expecting operating margins to be up +seventy bps to twenty.one
All in, we're taking our Cfifteen EPS estimate down to by dollar .two/sh
For Csixteen, we are lowering our EPS estimate by dollar .four/sh to dollar three.forty

Risk Disclosure Master limited partnerships are pass through entities structured as publicly listed partnerships.
For tax purposes, distributions to MLP unit holders may be treated as a return of principal.
Investors should consult their own tax advisors before investing in MLP units.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Below is the list of companies that constitute the industry coverage universe: U.S. Cosmetics; Household and Personal Care Avon Products Colgate Palmolive Jarden Corporation Procter and Gamble Distribution of Ratings: Barclays Equity Research has two thousand seven hundred seventy companies under coverage.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.
Top Picks: Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.
To view the current list of Top Picks, go to the Top Picks page on Barclays Live .
To see a list of companies that comprise a particular industry coverage universe, please go to http://publicresearch.barclays
